Award.AwardTitle: Multicultural Diversity in the Aquatic Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides funding to Hampton University to continue a program that aims to increase the number of students, particularly under-represented minority students, electing careers in aquatic sciences. The program recruits minority students and REU students, faculty and professionals interested in aquatic sciences, as well as faculty working at Historically Minority Colleges and Universities (HMCU). Participants received a free membership in the Association for the Sciences of Limnology and Oceanography (ASLO) and support to attend the annual meetings and special pre-meeting workshops that focus on current oceanographic or limnology research and on career advancement in the sciences. The present proposal will cultivate the development of past participants and incorporate new cohorts of students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Association for the Sciences of Limnology and Oceanography (ASLO) created the Multicultural Program (ASLOMP) in 1990 to address the lack of diversity in the workforce of aquatic scientists.  The National Science Foundation has supported the program from its inception.  In its most recent funding cycle (2014-2018) ASLOMP supported 70 – 80 diverse students each year to attend the annual meetings of ASLOMP and a variety of special activities.  The support includes transportation to and from the meetings, meeting registration, room and board.  ASLO provides the participants with free Society membership and a subscription to the societies’ journal.  Each student gave a platform or poster presentation on their research work. They also participated in all other aspects of the program including; an opening dinner with keynote speaker, a field trip, a student symposium for first-time presenters, a meeting-mentor program, special student-focused working sessions, and attendance of all regular ASLO activities. The program connected students with opportunities for internships, graduate school admission, and employment.  The participants were very diverse, including a variety of ethnic backgrounds, disciplinary interests in the aquatic sciences, some first-to-attend-college-in-family, others from rural area, some with disabilities (diverse-abilities), and those with different orientations. Most of the participants over the years earned advanced degrees. Many have returned to ASLOMP as mentors for subsequent cohorts.
